articles.headline: Palestinian Authority’s Future Is in Question
articles.snippet: Those close to Mahmoud Abbas said that he intended to resign and that other Palestinian officials would follow.
articles.abstract: Those close to Mahmoud Abbas said that he intended to resign and that other Palestinian officials would follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The collapse of the Palestinian Authority, Israel’s negotiating partner, was raised as a possibility on Monday, as several aides to its president, Mahmoud Abbas, said that he intended to resign and forecast that others would follow.

articles.headline: Justices Hear Patent Case on Protecting the Abstract
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court expressed skepticism about giving protection to abstract business innovations in a case that may reshape what can and cannot be patented.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court expressed skepticism about giving protection to abstract business innovations in a case that may reshape what can and cannot be patented.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Supreme Court justices took up a case on Monday that could reshape the realm of what can be patented, and expressed skepticism about giving protection to abstract business innovations.

articles.headline: U.S. Knew of Suspect’s Tie to Radical Cleric
articles.snippet: Authorities intercepted communications between Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan and a radical cleric but took no action, officials said.
articles.abstract: Authorities intercepted communications between Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan and a radical cleric but took no action, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Intelligence agencies intercepted communications last year and this year between the military psychiatrist accused of shooting to death 13 people at Fort Hood, Tex., and a radical cleric in Yemen known for his incendiary anti-American teachings.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Power for U.S. From Russia’s Old Nuclear Weapons
articles.snippet: Fuel from dismantled nuclear bombs, including Russian ones, generates about 10 percent of America’s electricity.
articles.abstract: Fuel from dismantled nuclear bombs, including Russian ones, generates about 10 percent of America’s electricity.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  What’s powering your home appliances?

articles.headline: Barclays’ Remarkable Bargain
articles.snippet: Heads are still being scratched over the way Barclays managed to scoop up the remains of Lehman Brothers. Barclays, it turns out, cut itself a remarkably good deal.
articles.abstract: Heads are still being scratched over the way Barclays managed to scoop up the remains of Lehman Brothers. Barclays, it turns out, cut itself a remarkably good deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: When is a good deal too good?

articles.headline: Trustee Seeks Billions for Madoff Investors
articles.snippet: The Madoff trustee has demanded the return of $7 billion he says Jeffry M. Picower and his wife withdrew from their accounts over decades.
articles.abstract: The Madoff trustee has demanded the return of $7 billion he says Jeffry M. Picower and his wife withdrew from their accounts over decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffry M. Picower, a longtime investor in Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud scheme who died in his Palm Beach swimming pool last month, left an estate with assets far in excess of $1 billion  and that could be a spot of good news for Mr. Madoff’s victims.

articles.headline: A Squeeze on Customers Ahead of New Rules
articles.snippet: Even the best cardholders are seeing their interest rates rise and credit lines get cut as financial firms struggle to make money in their card units.
articles.abstract: Even the best cardholders are seeing their interest rates rise and credit lines get cut as financial firms struggle to make money in their card units.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks are struggling to make money in the credit card business these days, and consumers are paying the price. Interest rates are going up, credit lines are being cut and a variety of new fees are being imposed on even the best cardholders.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Lowell Bergman

articles.headline: At Army Base, Some Violence Is Too Familiar
articles.snippet: For many, last week’s carnage was another blow in an area that has been beset by violence since the Iraq and Afghanistan wars began.
articles.abstract: For many, last week’s carnage was another blow in an area that has been beset by violence since the Iraq and Afghanistan wars began.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, Tex.  Staff Sgt. Gilberto Mota, 35, and his wife, Diana, 30, an Army specialist, had returned to Fort Hood from Iraq last year when he used his gun to kill her, and then took his own life, the authorities say. In July, two members of the First Cavalry Division, also just back from the war with decorations for their service, were at a party when one killed the other.
articles.byline: By Michael Moss and Ray Rivera
